articles.description:
WASHINGTON DC, Dec 04 (IPS) - The International Energy Agency now projects oil, gas, and coal use will all peak this decade. This constitutes a dramatic shift from the last 150 years when the thirst for fossil fuels persistently rose. But now this growth is nearing its end sooner than many expected, driven in part by a surge in renewables.

Read the full story, “From Peak Oil to Peak Energy? ... and Why It Matters”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: From Peak Oil to Peak Energy? ... and Why It Matters

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 04 (IPS) - Pacific people live at the nexus of oceans, climate, and food systems, and the interaction of climate and ocean is raising sea temperatures and threatening habitats and resources vital to the region’s sustenance, Palau’s President Surangel Whipps, Jr., said at the launch of an effort to protect and rejuvenate the region's ecosystems and empower communities through to the year 2050—in what is considered to be the biggest single conservation effort in history—Unlocking Blue Pacific Prosperity.

Read the full story, “Pacific Leaders Announce Largest Conservation Effort in History”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Pacific Leaders Announce Largest Conservation Effort in History

articles.description:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec 04 (IPS) - This year’s UN Climate Change Conference is taking place in Dubai from 30 November to 12 December. The so-called COP summits are organised every year and constitute a means for the global community to agree on ways to address the climate crisis, such as limiting global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius, supporting vulnerable communities to adapt to the effects of climate change, and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

Read the full story, “A Climate Scientist’s View of COP 28”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Climate Scientist’s View of COP 28

articles.description:
KATHMANDU, Nepal, Dec 04 (IPS) - If there is an agency or program within the UN that I really admire and wish the best for, this is the United Nation Volunteers or UNV. Its overarching mission, mandate and key objectives are paramount for humanity.

Read the full story, “UN Volunteers and Their Over Reaching Mission”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UN Volunteers  and Their Over Reaching Mission

articles.description:
LONDON, Dec 04 (IPS) - The Netherlands is the latest country to lurch to the right amid the global cost of living crisis. Its November election saw maverick far-right populist Geert Wilders and his Party for Freedom (PVV) come first. A hardline Islamophobe who’s called for the Quran to be banned could be the next prime minister.

Read the full story, “Netherlands Latest Country to Tilt to the Right”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Netherlands Latest Country to Tilt to the Right

articles.description:
JOHANNESBURG & TASHKENT, Dec 04 (IPS) - Lawmakers were reminded of the benefits of long-term planning and the benefits of evidence-based decision-making in policymaking while grappling with demographic trends, be they an aging population or one with significant growth in youth, like that of Uzbekistan.

Read the full story, “Lawmakers Told: Plan From the Cradle For Healthy Aging”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Lawmakers Told: Plan From the Cradle For Healthy Aging

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 04 (IPS) - Across the globe, the number of crisis-affected school-aged children facing climate shocks amplified by climate change keeps rising. The Somalia region of Ethiopia is facing the worst drought in 40 years. Last year in Pakistan, unprecedented flooding damaged more than 26,000 schools. Tropical Cyclone Tej recently made landfall in Yemen, affecting thousands of people.

Read the full story, “ECWs Emergency Appeal for Crises Impacted Children Facing Double Tragedies”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: ECWs Emergency Appeal for Crises Impacted Children Facing Double Tragedies

articles.description:

articles.title: Iraq: UN team issues latest report on terrorist atrocities

articles.title: UN chief calls on Israel to ‘spare civilians from more suffering’ in Gaza

articles.description:
Flooding in Somalia has uprooted more than one million people and killed 110, UN humanitarians in the country said in their latest situation report on Monday.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Somalia floods, Sudan cholera update, genocide prevention”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Somalia floods, Sudan cholera update, genocide prevention

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 03 (IPS) - Yamide Dagnet, the Director for Climate Justice at Open Society Foundations, delves into the intricacies of the negotiations at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 27th session of the Conference of Parties (COP28) in Dubai.As the world converges for COP 28, the urgency of addressing climate change has never been more palpable. In an exclusive interview with IPS, Yamide Dagnet, the Director for Climate Justice at Open Society Foundations, delves into the intricate details of this pivotal conference—from the unprecedented start to key challenges and opportunities in climate finance. She offers a comprehensive and nuanced perspective on global climate discourse.

Read the full story, “Human Rights Crucial as Wealthy Nations Reap Energy Transition Benefits”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Human Rights Crucial as Wealthy Nations Reap Energy Transition Benefits

articles.description:
Health has made it onto the agenda of a UN climate conference, and health advocates at COP28 in Dubai on Sunday said the topic was long overdue for discussion as climate inaction is costing lives and impacting health every single day.

Read the full story, “COP28: The climate crisis is also a health crisis”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: COP28: The climate crisis is also a health crisis

articles.description:
The resumption of hostilities in Gaza and its terrifying impact on civilians underscore the need for the violence to end and a long-term political solution between Palestinians and Israelis to be found, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Sunday.

Read the full story, “Gaza: UN rights chief appeals for end to violence and a return to dialogue”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza: UN rights chief appeals for end to violence and a return to dialogue

articles.description:
UN Secretary-General António Guterres on Sunday sent a strong message to the oil and gas industry: the pledges made at COP28 in Dubai fall well short of what’s needed to meaningfully tackle the climate crisis.

Read the full story, “COP28: Methane pledge by the ‘giants behind the climate crisis’ falls short, says Guterres”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: COP28: Methane pledge by the ‘giants behind the climate crisis’ falls short, says Guterres

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 02 (IPS) - The Feminist Green New Deal Coalition has highlighted feminist climate solutions and shared feminist policies and frameworks that are advancing just climate policies at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 27th session of the Conference of Parties (COP28) in Dubai.

Read the full story, “Why is There Funding for War But Never for Climate finance, Ask Feminists”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Why is There Funding for War But Never for Climate finance, Ask Feminists

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
SUBSCRIBER+EXCLUSIVE REPORTING — In the days after Hamas fighters launched a terrorist attack in Israel in October, an illicit amphetamine known as Captagon was reportedly found in [...] More 
The post How the Captagon Trade is Bolstering Iran and its Web of Militias appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: How the Captagon Trade is Bolstering Iran and its Web of Militias

Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Scientists have discovered the Lost City Hydrothermal Field, an otherworldly environment with towering structures and a thriving ecosystem. This hydrothermal field is located close to an underwater mountain west of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. It features creamy carbonate towers, some up to 60 meters tall. The Lost City is unique because it has sustained its existence for at least 120,000 years and contains hydrocarbons formed on the deep seafloor....
articles.title: Scientists uncover 'Lost City' beneath Atlantic Ocean

articles.description: Alaska Airlines announces intent to purchase Hawaiian Airlines for $1.9 billion, awaiting regulatory approval. Merger would create nation's fifth-largest carrier, with combined fleet of 365 aircraft serving 138 destinations. Potential benefits include expanded connections to U.S., Asia, and the Pacific. Regulatory scrutiny expected due to reduced competition in Hawaii. Acquisition reflects industry trend of consolidation to navigate financial challenges.
articles.title: Alaska Airlines to acquire Hawaiian Airlines in $1.9 billion deal

articles.description: Pakistan's Election Commission has asked the government to deploy regular army troops to ensure security during the general election scheduled for February 8, 2024. The commission stated that the provincial police force is insufficient, requiring at least 591,106 security personnel. There is a shortage of 277,558 police personnel in the provinces and federation. The demand for army deployment is not new in Pakistan. The caretaker Information Minister assured that the government will provide the necessary funds, as approved by the Cabinet, for the Election Commission's needs. Finance Secretary Imdadullah Bosal confirmed that the funds will be released within two days.
articles.title: Pakistan's election body asks govt to deploy army on general election day

articles.description: EU envoys meet to debate membership talks with Ukraine, despite Hungary's threat to block. Decisions on integration prospects for Moldova, Georgia, and Bosnia also expected at the summit. Hungary argues that Ukraine is not ready due to corruption and ongoing conflict. Hungary's concerns may complicate negotiations. Other EU countries seek to advance the prospects of Georgia and Bosnia in exchange for supporting Ukraine. EU aid to Hungary has been unlocked to sway Budapest's decision.
articles.title: EU states to start debating Ukraine membership talks on Tuesday

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Joan Donovan, a disinformation scholar, accuses Harvard University of infringing on her free speech by dismissing her, potentially to appease Facebook. Donovan's termination, allegedly linked to Harvard's $500 million pledge from Meta founder Mark Zuckerberg, is seen as compromising academic freedom and prioritizing the interests of the tech giant. Harvard denies Donovan's claims, asserting that she was a staff employee and offering her a part-time role, which she declined.
articles.title: Harvard accused of favouring Facebook by disinformation scholar

articles.description: Tanzanian Prime Minister Kassim Majaliwa pays tribute to the 63 people killed in landslides and flooding in Katesh. The toll is expected to rise. Torrential downpours caused the disaster, washing away vehicles and buildings. Rescue operations are underway with the help of the military. The floods exacerbate the humanitarian crisis in the region, which is recovering from a severe drought. The president has cut short her visit to Dubai for the COP28 climate talks.
articles.title: Death toll from Tanzania landslides rises to 63

articles.description: Putin discussed disrupted cooperation between Moscow and Berlin due to the blasts in September 2022 that affected the Nord Stream pipelines. He mentioned this during a ceremony in the Kremlin while accepting new foreign ambassadors. Putin emphasized that the current frozen state of relations is unprofitable for both countries, especially Germany. He highlighted that energy cooperation was disrupted by the sabotage on the Nord Stream pipelines. Russia has accused the United States, Britain, and Ukraine of the pipeline blasts, but they have all denied any involvement. Putin also expressed hope for improved relations between Moscow and London.
articles.title: Putin blames Nord Stream blasts for disruption of Russia-Germany relations

articles.description: A Kenyan court on Monday suspended a government plan to start a fresh privatisation drive under a modified law while it hears a challenge that an opposition party has brought against the sales. In late November the finance ministry said it would start the process of offering to sell its shareholding in 11 firms, including an oil pipeline, a textbook publisher and agribusiness firms. The 11 companies are among more than 35 companies that are lined up for sale, partly to help the government raise revenue in the face of growing debt repayments.
articles.title: Kenyan court suspends plan to privatise more state-owned firms

articles.description: Argentina's president-elect Javier Milei appoints Rodolfo Barra, a former justice minister, as the attorney general of the treasury. Barra's appointment has sparked controversy due to his past involvement in an ultranationalist movement and anti-Semitism claims. The Argentine Forum Against Anti-Semitism and opposition politicians have protested against Barra's appointment, calling it a direct affront to the democratic and plural spirit of the country. Barra had previously apologized for his past behavior, but concerns remain about his suitability for the role.
articles.title: Argentina's Milei picks former pro-Nazi youth for top legal post

articles.description: Israeli and Palestinian representatives at the UN Human Rights Council traded accusations of 'genocide' over the war in Gaza. Israel's war against Hamas and the resulting man-made catastrophe were discussed. The Israeli representative highlighted the genocidal ideology of Hamas and the online anti-Semitism faced by the Jewish people. The Palestinian representative emphasized the massive bombing campaign by Israel and called for early action under the genocide convention. Other Muslim countries accused Israel of incitement to genocide, and concerns were raised about the failure to prevent genocide and the repression of Palestinian voices online.
articles.title: Israel, Palestinians accuse each other of 'genocide' at UN

articles.description: Torrential downpours in Katesh, northern Tanzania, caused landslides and flooding, resulting in at least 57 deaths and many more trapped. President Samia Suluhu Hassan, who cut short her visit to Dubai for climate talks, confirmed the casualties. Regional commissioner Queen Sendiga initially reported 47 dead. The military is assisting with search and rescue operations as thick mud hampers efforts. The floods compound the humanitarian crisis in East Africa, which is recovering from a severe drought. Human-induced climate change is making extreme weather events more frequent and intense.
articles.title: Death toll from Tanzania landslides rises to 57

articles.description: Pakistan anti-corruption court summons former PM Imran Khan and wife Bushra Bibi for the Al-Qadir Trust case. Non-bailable arrest warrants issued for six others, including Malik Riaz Hussain, in the Al-Qadir Trust corruption case. Judge orders Khan's production from Adiala Jail and directs Bibi to appear. Next hearing to be held at Adiala Jail. Charges allege Khan and Bibi obtained billions of rupees and land from Bahria Town Ltd to legalize Rs50 billion returned from the UK.
articles.title: Pakistan court summons Imran Khan, wife on December 6 in Al-Qadir case

articles.description: Israeli authorities are investigating claims that some investors may have profited from Israeli securities by short-selling shares based on advance knowledge of a Hamas plan to attack Israel. Law professors Robert Jackson Jr and Joshua Mitts found significant short-selling of the MSCI Israel ETF and Israeli securities on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange leading up to the attacks. The matter is under investigation by the Israel Securities Authority and relevant parties. The researchers also discovered a sharp increase in trading of risky short-dated options on Israeli companies just before the attacks.
articles.title: Israel investigates possible trading knowledge ahead of October 7 Hamas attack

articles.description: At least 83 Spanish media outlets had filed a USD 598 million lawsuit against Meta platforms for unfair competition in the advertising market. The AMI newspaper filed a lawsuit with the media association. The newspapers said Meta's "massive" and "systematic" use of personal data from the users of its Facebook, Instagram, and Whatsapp platforms allows it to get an unfair advantage in designing and offering personalized ads that constitute unfair competition.
articles.title: Spanish media association files $598 million lawsuit against Facebook owner Meta

articles.description: Harvard University faces alumni dissatisfaction and a substantial decline in donations due to concerns over the handling of a campus crisis, including reports of antisemitism. The university's fundraising operation, which relies on volunteers, is struggling to assuage these concerns while maintaining financial support. The financial impact of this alumni revolt is uncertain, but it poses a reputational risk and could have a significant effect on Harvard's annual revenue.
articles.title: Why many alums are making just $1 donations to Harvard

articles.description: Narges Mohammadi, the jailed Iranian Nobel Peace Prize winner, vows to continue her fight for human rights, even if it means risking her life. Currently serving multiple sentences in Tehran's Evin prison, she is accused of spreading propaganda against the Islamic Republic. Her imprisonment and psychological torture have not deterred her. She started a hunger strike to protest the prison's lack of medical care. In a letter smuggled out from prison, she expresses her longing for her children.
articles.title: Jailed Nobel winner Mohammadi to continue protests, she says in smuggled letter

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Residents of Scranton, Pennsylvania, offer a spectrum of opinions on President Biden's recent claim to view the U.S. economy through their eyes. Critical voices express skepticism and criticize Biden as the worst president. Local leaders express sentiments through controversial roadway renamings. Varied opinions question Biden's connection to Scranton, with some uncertainty about the 2024 race. Scranton residents criticize the state of the economy and express weariness with political scandals.
articles.title: Biden's hometown speaks: Scranton residents 'critical' of 'Bidenomics'

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: U.S. and Japanese rescuers discover wreckage and identify remains of crew members from crashed Osprey aircraft. U.S. Air Force reports breakthrough in recovery efforts, retrieving main fuselage and remains. Crash prompts suspension of flights for Japan's Osprey fleet. Identification of remains underway. Incident reignites discussions about Japan-U.S. Status of Forces Agreement. Tragedy raises questions about crash cause and safety of Osprey aircraft.
articles.title: US military discovers remains of five Osprey crash victims off Japan's coast

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: China accuses US of violating sovereign waters in South China Sea; USS Gabrielle Giffords allegedly illegally intruded near Second Thomas Shoal; Chinese naval force monitors American warship's movements; Philippines seeks American assistance in territorial conflicts; China accuses US of meddling in the region, escalating tensions; USS Gabrielle Giffords becomes focal point of dispute; China insists on its right over the South China Sea; concerns over potential for further military confrontations
articles.title: US denies China's allegations of naval intrusion in the South China Sea

articles.description: Britain's armed forces face a funding shortfall of 17 billion pounds over the next 10 years, the largest deficit since 2012. The budget for new weapons and equipment is estimated at 305.5 billion pounds for 2023-2033, 16.9 billion pounds over budget. Soaring costs in nuclear and naval programs, as well as high inflation, have pushed up the future budget. The Ministry of Defence's financial position has deteriorated. Russia's war in Ukraine has highlighted the need for extra military spending across Europe, with Britain as an important ally and provider of military equipment to Kyiv.
articles.title: UK military faces $22 billion equipment shortfall, watchdog says

articles.description: A bomb attack on a Catholic mass in Marawi, Philippines, at Mindanao State University's gymnasium left at least four dead and dozens wounded. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the blast, which occurred during a morning service. The explosion was caused by an improvised explosive device. The university condemned the violence and suspended classes, while the city's mayor called for unity among Muslim and Christian communities.
articles.title: Four killed in bomb attack on Catholic mass in Philippines

articles.description: MANILA: A magnitude 6.
articles.title: Magnitude 6.9 earthquake strikes off southern Philippines: USGS

articles.description: A man went on a knife attack, killing four relatives, including two children, at their New York City home. He then set the building on fire and stabbed two police officers before being shot. The incident occurred in Far Rockaway, Queens. The police officers were responding to a 911 call from a young female who reported her cousin was killing her family. The suspect, identified as Courtney Gordon, had been visiting the family from the Bronx. This incident follows a similar knife rampage in the Bronx last week.
articles.title: Man kills 4 relatives in Queens knife rampage, injures 2 officers before he's fatally shot by police

articles.description: Israeli PM Netanyahu discusses ongoing hostage release efforts in Gaza, emphasizing strategic decision-making. He urges caution among Likud ministers, calls for unity and focus on all fronts. Netanyahu expresses the need for a thorough inquiry into the shooting incident involving Yuval Doron Castleman, a hero who tragically lost his life. The incident prompts public outcry, leading to the involvement of the IDF in the investigation. The situation remains tense as Israel addresses security concerns and continues military operations to secure the release of hostages.
articles.title: 'Speaking with Fire': Benjamin Netanyahu affirms ongoing talks with Hamas on hostage release

articles.description: US officials to visit Pakistan in December for consultations on various issues including the ongoing situation in Afghanistan; both countries exchanging visits to speed up the process; Pakistan blames Afghanistan for terrorist attacks and usage of Afghan oil for attacks; recent attack resulted in casualties; Pakistan deporting illegal Afghan citizens; US Assistant Secretary of State for the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration to visit Pakistan; discussions not limited to Afghanistan concerns.
articles.title: US officials to visit Pakistan in December to discuss Afghanistan, other issues

articles.description: Israel struck Gaza targets in its war on Hamas. The civilian death toll increased, causing international concern. More than 15,500 people have been killed in the Palestinian territory. Israeli air and artillery strikes hit Gaza, while rockets were launched from Gaza into Israel. The UN reported 160 Palestinian deaths in two incidents. The Israeli army said it had carried out 10,000 air strikes, located more than 800 shafts to Hamas tunnels destroyed 500 Hamas tunnels.
articles.title: Israel bombs Gaza as pressure mounts to protect civilians

articles.description: European far-right parties gathered in Italy to strategize for the upcoming European Parliament elections. They aim to reshape the European Union by adopting tougher immigration policies and relaxing climate regulations to safeguard jobs and industry. The meeting was inspired by Geert Wilders' PVV party's unexpected success in the recent Dutch elections. Italian Deputy Prime Minister Salvini, the host, aspires for their alliance to become the third-largest group in the EU Parliament.
articles.title: Far-right parties eye gains in next year's EU parliament elections

articles.description: Italy's culture minister rejects the German State Antiquities Collection's request to return the Discobolus Palombara, a 2nd-century Roman copy of a Greek bronze statue that embodied Hitler's Aryan aesthetic. Hitler acquired the statue in 1938 against the wishes of Italian officials. The statue was returned to Italy in 1948. The dispute now involves the director of the National Roman Museum requesting the return of the statue's marble base from the German museum.
articles.title: Italy refuses Munich museum's request to return ancient Roman statue bought by Adolf Hitler

articles.description: The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC), Karim Khan, announced that the ICC will intensify investigations into possible crimes committed by Hamas and Israeli forces. The ICC has been looking into crimes in the Palestinian territories since 2021, but has not yet filed any charges. Khan witnessed "scenes of calculated cruelty" during his visit to locations of the October 7 attacks by Hamas. He called for the release of hostages taken by Hamas.
articles.title: After visiting Israel and Ramallah, the ICC prosecutor says he will intensify investigations

articles.description: Guinea-Bissau's President Umaro Sissoco Embalo confirmed that the recent shootout in the capital was an attempted coup, following the improper release of two ministers detained over corruption allegations. President Embalo dismissed the head of the National Guard and warned of consequences for everyone involved. This attempted coup adds to the growing number of military takeovers in West and Central Africa. The incident has garnered deep concern from the regional economic bloc.
articles.title: Guinea-Bissau's leader calls a shootout an attempted coup, heightening tensions in West Africa

articles.description: A man wielding a steak knife killed four members of his extended family in Queens, New York City. The incident was reported by a girl in the Far Rockaway neighborhood. The suspect, a 38-year-old, stabbed two police officers who responded to the scene, but was shot dead by one of the officers. The suspect had a history of domestic violence. The police had to wait for the fire department to arrive before entering the home, as the suspect had set fire to a couch.
articles.title: Man stabs four to death in New York's Queens, police shoot him dead

articles.description: Brazilian President Lula da Silva visits Berlin for Brazilian-German government consultations to revive ties after years of diplomatic isolation. Lula aims to restore Brazil's global standing after his predecessor Jair Bolsonaro. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, the first foreign leader to visit Lula, seeks to improve ties with the Global South. Both countries push for a quick trade deal between the EU and Mercosur. The visit highlights their differences over the Israel-Hamas war.
articles.title: Lula in Berlin for first Brazil-Germany talks in eight years

articles.description: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo urges lawmakers, Silicon Valley, and US allies to prevent China from acquiring semiconductors and cutting-edge technologies crucial for national security. Raimondo emphasizes that China is the biggest threat, stating that they are not a friend. She highlights the role of her department in the fierce rivalry. Raimondo calls for tighter export controls, better funding to protect America's leadership in artificial intelligence and advanced semiconductor design.
articles.title: US Commerce chief Gina Raimondo warns against China 'threat'

articles.description: Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko, a staunch ally of Moscow, is visiting China on Sunday and Monday to meet his counterpart Xi Jinping, the Belarusian presidency said.  On Monday, he will hold talks with Xi on issues including "trade, the economy, investment and international cooperation", the presidency announced on Sunday.
articles.title: Belarus leader Alexander Lukashenko visits China to meet Xi Jinping

articles.description: Ukrainian officials accuse Russian forces of killing surrendering Ukrainian soldiers. It will be a war crime if confirmed. Video footage shows two uniformed men being shot at close range after surrendering. Ukrainian General Prosecutor's Office launches criminal investigation. Kyiv accuses Moscow of breaching international humanitarian law since the invasion of Ukraine. Ukrainian energy ministry reports power outages in towns and villages due to wintry weather and ongoing fighting.
articles.title: Kyiv says Russian forces shot surrendering Ukrainian soldiers

articles.description: India agrees to withdraw soldiers from the Maldives as President Mohamed Muizzu announces the decision. Muizzu campaigned to change the Maldives's 'India first' policy and remove the small Indian military presence. Indian government agreed to remove soldiers and establish a committee for development projects. Indian military personnel were mainly present to operate helicopters and aircraft, assist in disaster response, and help build a naval dockyard.
articles.title: India agrees to withdraw soldiers from Maldives: President Muizzu

articles.description: Heavy snow in northern England caused motorists to be stranded in their cars and resulted in power outages for over 2,500 customers. Trucks blocked highways, leaving drivers stuck and in need of emergency assistance. The Lake District community of Ambleside experienced severe weather conditions, resembling an Alpine ski resort. Emergency services, including the Cumbria Fire & Rescue Service and Cumbria Police, worked tirelessly to rescue stranded travelers.
articles.title: Heavy snow in northern England causes havoc on highways and knocks out power

articles.description: An Indian Sikh pilgrim in his 70s died in Lahore due to cardiac arrest. The body was handed over to the BSF at Wagah border. Another Sikh family was looted by robbers in police uniforms during Guru Nanak Dev's birth anniversary festivities in Lahore. Punjab's caretaker CM Mohsin Naqvi ordered the police to arrest the culprits within 48 hours, but no progress has been made in the case.  Naqvi had ordered the Punjab police to arrest the culprits within 48 hours.
articles.title: Indian Sikh pilgrim dies due to cardiac arrest in Pakistan's Punjab province

articles.description: A magnitude 6.6 earthquake, followed by several strong aftershocks, hit Mindanao island, Philippines, triggering a tsunami alert. The earthquake occurred near Hinatuan municipality, the same area affected by a magnitude 7.6 quake the night before. Two people were killed in Bislig City and Tagum city, and several others were injured. There were no major damages reported, but cracked roads in Bislig City were observed. The earthquake also caused small swells in Japan's eastern Pacific coast.
articles.title: Magnitude 6.6 aftershock causes panic in southern Philippines

articles.description: Mount Marapi, an active volcano in western Indonesia, erupted on Sunday, spewing a three-kilometer column of ash into the sky. Dozens of hikers were evacuated from the area. The volcano, with a peak of 2,891 meters, is on the third-highest alert level in Indonesia. Authorities have imposed an exclusion zone around the crater. While there are no immediate reports of damage or casualties, 42 hikers are currently unaccounted for. Efforts are underway to ensure their safety and evacuation of others.
articles.title: Hikers evacuated as Indonesia volcano spews ash tower

articles.description: North Korea's reconnaissance satellite operation office, functioning as a military intelligence organisation, started its mission on Saturday. The office, located at the Pyongyang General Control Centre of the National Aerospace Technology Administration (NATA), will report acquired information to the reconnaissance bureau at the army and other major units.  Despite no released imagery, analysts and foreign governments debate its capability. South Korea also launched its own spy satellite this month.
articles.title: North Korea begins reconnaissance satellite operations -KCNA

articles.description: PARIS: One person died and another was injured after an assailant attacked passersby in central Paris near the Eiffel Tower, Interior Minister Gerald .
articles.title: One dead, one injured after assailant attacks passersby in Paris -minister

articles.description: Israeli forces and Hezbollah militants exchanged heavy fire across the Israel-Lebanon border throughout Saturday as hostilities intensified following the collapse of a truce in Gaza between Palestinian group Hamas and Israel. The Israeli military and Iranian-backed Hezbollah both said they had struck enemy targets, but despite the heavy exchanges in multiple locations along the border, only one casualty was reported. Hezbollah said one of its fighters was killed.
articles.title: Israel, Hezbollah trade fire after Israel-Hamas truce ends

articles.description: The power in Afghanistan is now in the hands of religious scholars who understand the interests and priorities of the country. The Taliban-appointed acting Interior Minister, Sirajuddin Haqqani, met with a delegation of scholars from Islamic countries to discuss security, economic stability, and construction. The Taliban has achieved success in fighting against narcotics, corruption, ensuring security, stability. Political analysts believe that the visit of the delegation can be effective.
articles.title: Power in Afghanistan in hands of religious scholars: Taliban

articles.description: Queen Tunku Azizah Aminah Maimunah Iskandariah of Malaysia, along with her accompanying delegation, visited the headquarters of the General Women's Union (GWU) in Abu Dhabi.
articles.title: Queen of Malaysia visits General Women's Union

articles.description: PESHAWAR: At least seven people were killed and eighteen injured as terrorists opened fire on a passenger bus in restive northwest Pakistan on Saturda.
articles.title: Seven persons killed in terror attack in Pakistan's Gilgit Baltistan

articles.description: The Biden administration issues a final rule to reduce methane emissions from the oil and gas industry, promoting the use of cutting-edge methane detection technologies. The rule will deliver significant public health benefits. It is announced at the UN climate conference that 50 oil companies have pledged to reach near-zero methane emissions and end routine flaring by 2030. Vice President Kamala Harris emphasizes the need for bold action to confront climate change.
articles.title: US targets oil and natural gas industry's role in global warming with new rule on methane emissions

articles.description: The resignation of Portugal's Socialist government will be official from Thursday, a month after Prime Minister Antonio Costa stepped down after being implicated in an influence-peddling probe, the country's president said. The probe involving Costa and others covers alleged "misuse of funds, active and passive corruption by political figures, and influence peddling," according to a statement from public prosecutors.
articles.title: Resignation of Portugal government to be official next week

articles.description: Remington Arms, the country's oldest gun maker, is set to close its gun factory in Ilion, New York, in March. The factory has a history dating back to the 19th century and currently employs about 270 workers. The decision to close the facility was not taken lightly, according to a letter from the company to union officials. RemArms, the current version of Remington Arms, faced temporary closures, bankruptcy, and legal pressure following the Sandy Hook school massacre.
articles.title: Gun factory in upstate New York with roots in 19th century set to close

articles.description: Palestinian human rights groups refuse to meet International Criminal Court prosecutor Karim Khan, accusing him of favoring Israeli accusations of rights abuses over longstanding Palestinian charges. Khan has been visiting Israel and the occupied West Bank following a request by a group representing families of victims of the Oct 7 attack on Israel by Hamas gunmen. Accusations of war crimes and human rights abuses have been made on both sides since Oct 7.
articles.title: Palestinian rights groups snub ICC prosecutor

articles.title: Gaza strikes intensify as U.S. warns Israel over civilian deaths

articles.description: At least four people were killed and at least 50 injured after a bomb exploded during a morning Catholic Mass in a university gymnasium in Marawi.
articles.title: ''Foreign Terrorists'' Behind Philippine Bombing That Killed 4: President

articles.description: India's government has agreed to withdraw its soldiers from the Maldives, the Indian Ocean archipelago's President Mohamed Muizzu said on Sunday. Muizzu won the presidential
articles.title: India Agrees To Withdraw Soldiers From Maldives: President Mohamed Muizzu

articles.description: A Paraguayan lawmaker and three other people died in a plane crash in the South American country on Saturday, local police said.
articles.title: Paraguayan Lawmaker, Three Others Die In Plane Crash: Cops

articles.description: North Korea's reconnaissance satellite operation office began its mission as a military intelligence organisation, state news agency KCNA said on Sunday.
articles.title: N Korea's Reconnaissance Satellite Operation Office Begins Mission: Report

articles.description: An assailant killed a German tourist in a knife attack in the heart of Paris on Saturday and later told police that he could not bear the deaths of Muslims in Afghanistan and the occupied Palestinian territories, the French interior minister said.
articles.title: Man Stabbed To Death In Paris: Look At Attacks In France In Recent Years

articles.description: Israel faced growing U.S. calls to avoid further harm to Palestinian civilians in its fight against Hamas militants in Gaza, as the warring sides on Sunday showed no sign of moving toward reviving their collapsed truce.
articles.title: Israel Faces Growing US Calls For Restraint Amid Renewed Gaza Fighting

articles.description: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo on Saturday urged lawmakers, Silicon Valley and US allies to stop China from getting semiconductors and cutting-edge technologies key to national security.
articles.title: China "Not Our Friend, Biggest Threat We've Ever Had": US Commerce Chief

articles.description: An attacker stabbed one man to death and wounded two others in Paris on Saturday, reportedly shouting "Allahu Akbar" ("God is greatest") before being arrested, French police sources told AFP.
articles.title: Paris Attacker Known To Follow Radical Islam, Has Mental Illness: Report

articles.description: After two days of back-to-back speeches by world leaders, the COP28 climate summit turns its attention on Sunday to the reality of climate change fuelling more sickness and disease.
articles.title: Bill Gates May Launch Climate Health Initiative At COP28 Today

articles.description: One person died and two others were injured after a man attacked tourists in central Paris near the Eiffel Tower, Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin said on Saturday.
articles.title: 1 Dead After Man "Upset Over Muslims Dying" Attacks Tourists In Paris

articles.description: At almost exactly the same time Israeli negotiators pulled out of deadlocked truce talks in Qatar on Saturday, Israeli jets sent a prestige Doha-funded housing development in the Gaza Strip up in smoke.
articles.title: 5 Israeli Air Strikes Rain Down Qatar-Funded Gaza Complex In 2 Minutes

articles.description: Israeli hostages released from Gaza spoke publicly Saturday for the first time and urged their government to secure the release of the remaining captives held in the war-torn Palestinian territory.
articles.title: Freed Israeli Hostages Call For Captives' Release

articles.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said his country will do everything for the International Criminal Court (ICC) to punish Israel for the genocide in the Gaza Strip, Russian news agency TASS reported.
articles.title: Erdogan Says Turkey Will Do Everything For World Court To Punish Israel

articles.description: Guinea-Bissau's President Umaro Sissoco Embalo on Saturday said this week's deadly violence involving members of the National Guard was an "attempted coup" as the army ordered them back to barracks.
articles.title: Guinea-Bissau President Calls Deadly Violence An "Attempted Coup"

articles.description: US Vice President Kamala Harris said too many innocent Palestinians had been killed in Gaza as Israeli war planes and artillery bombarded the enclave on Saturday following the collapse of a truce with Hamas militants.
articles.title: "Too Many Innocent Palestinians Have Been Killed": Kamala Harris

articles.description: Gunmen attacked a bus near the town of Chilas in northern Pakistan on Saturday, killing eight passengers and injuring at least 15, district and regional officials said.
articles.title: 8 Bus Passengers Killed, 15 Injured By Unknown Gunmen In Northern Pak

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Saturday the war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip would continue "until we achieve all its aims", including returning all Israeli hostages and eliminating the Islamist movement.
articles.title: Netanyahu Says War In Gaza To Continue "Until We Achieve All Its Aims"

articles.description: The first woman to serve as an officer of justice at the United States Supreme Court, Sandra Day O'Connor, died at the age of 93 in Phoenix on Friday, The New York Times reported.
articles.title: Sandra Day O'Connor, First Woman On US Supreme Court, Dead At 93

articles.description: The Biden administration on Saturday unveiled final rules aimed at cracking down on US oil and gas industry releases of methane, part of a global plan to rein in emissions that contribute to climate change.
articles.title: At COP28, US Unveils Plan To Cut Oil, Gas Industry's Methane Emissions

articles.description: Deputy Hamas chief Saleh Al-Arouri told the pan-Arab Al Jazeera TV on Saturday that no more prisoners would be exchanged with Israel until there was a ceasefire in Gaza.
articles.title: No Prisoner Exchange With Israel Until There Is Ceasefire In Gaza: Hamas

articles.description: After a gruelling six-month-long search, missing US teen Valerie Tindall's body was found buried in her 59-year-old neighbour's backyard in Indiana.
articles.title: "Like Jealous Boyfriend...": US Teen's Mother On Neighbour Who Killed Her

articles.description: A powerful magnitude 7.6 earthquake struck the southern Philippines on Saturday, the US Geological Survey said, as local authorities warned of a "destructive tsunami" and urged people in coastal areas to flee.

articles.title: Niger’s junta revokes key security agreements with EU and turns to Russia for defense partnership

articles.description: The French parliament is considering a ban on single-use, disposable electronic cigarettes that are popular with teenagers for their sweet flavors and are under scrutiny as a new source of trash
articles.title: France's parliament considers a ban on single-use e-cigarettes

articles.title: The trial of 4 Egyptian security officials in the slaying of an Italian student is set for February

articles.description: French investigations into a fatal weekend attack near the Eiffel Tower are looking into the suspect's mental health
articles.title: After a fatal attack near the Eiffel Tower, French investigators look into suspect's mental health

articles.description: Police in Berlin have been alerted to an overnight fire at the office of an Iranian opposition group in the German capital, and are investigating the incident as a suspected arson attempt
articles.title: Berlin police investigate a suspected arson attempt at Iran opposition group's office

articles.title: Guinea-Bissau’s president has dissolved the West African nation’s parliament after last week’s failed coup

articles.description: Border officials in South Africa say they have intercepted dozens of buses carrying more than 400 young children from Zimbabwe without parents or legal guardians in an anti-trafficking operation
articles.title: South Africa intercepts buses carrying more than 400 unaccompanied kids from Zimbabwe

articles.description: Authorities say at least 47 people are dead and 85 others injured following heavy flooding and landslides in northern Tanzania
articles.title: Heavy rains and landslides in Tanzania kill at least 47, authorities say

articles.description: Russian officials and media say that heavy snowfall that hit Moscow has disrupted traffic on roads and flights in and out of three airports
articles.title: Heavy snowfall hits Moscow as Russian media report disruption on roads and at airports

articles.title: U.S. Air Force says divers have found remains and wreckage from an Osprey aircraft that crashed off southwestern Japan

articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un says it is a duty of women to halt a fall in the country’s birthrate
articles.title: North Korean leader calls for women to have more children to halt a fall in birthrate

articles.description: Turkey's disaster management agency says a moderately strong earthquake has struck the country's northwest, sending people out into the streets in fear
articles.title: Magnitude 5.1 earthquake shakes northwest Turkey. No damage or injuries reported

articles.title: French foreign minister says she is open to South Pacific resettlement requests due to rising seas

articles.title: Indonesian rescuers recover 11 bodies of climbers in their search for 26 people still missing after volcanic eruption

articles.title: Widespread flooding has already killed hundreds in East Africa

articles.description: A Bostom woman was killed in a shark attack near a Sandals resort on Nassau, Bahamas. She and a male relative were paddle boarding when she was attacked. Elaine Quijano reports.

articles.description: Rocha allegedly spied on behalf of Cuba's intelligence agency, referred to the U.S. as "the enemy" and supported Cuba's clandestine intelligence-gathering mission, according to prosecutors.

articles.description: The woman and a male relative were paddle boarding at a resort about 3/4 mile away from the shore when she was bitten by the shark.

articles.description: A U.S. Navy warship shot down several drones launched toward commercial ships in the Red Sea. Iranian-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen have claimed responsibility for the attacks. David Martin reports.

articles.description: Israel has resumed airstrikes and a ground assault in the Gaza Strip, turning its firepower to the southern part of the Palestinian territory, where Israel had originally told civilians to flee at the start of the war. Over 100 hostages, including several Americans, still remain in Gaza. Charlie D'Agata reports.

articles.description: Big bets against Israeli stocks before Oct. 7 suggests someone may have known about the attack in advance, a new study says.

articles.description: It beat out words such as prompt, situationship and Swiftie. Here's what rizz means.

articles.description: The Israeli military said Sunday its ground offensive has expanded to every part of Gaza after a week-long pause in hostilities between Israel and Hamas. With the temporary cease-fire over, hostages remain in Gaza. CBS News' Chris Livesay spoke to the parents of American hostage Hersh Goldberg-Polin, who have a message for their son.

articles.description: The sighting came just days after scientists declared the iceberg was "on the move" for the first time in 37 years.

articles.description: A researcher behind a study of wasabi's effect on cognition says he knew the fiery condiment had health benefits, but "the dramatic change" in memory was a surprise.

articles.description: Monique Olivier, standing trial in Paris, is accused of involvement in the murders by Michel Fourniret of two young women, including British student Joanna Parrish.

articles.description: Spiking temperatures in the Arctic are rapidly melting glaciers. Scientists are now worried about underground methane, a potent greenhouse gas, leaking up to the surface.

articles.description: The victim was trying to boost her child aboard a floating play platform when the shark bit her, officials said.

articles.description: A large part of the fuselage of a U.S. Air Force CV-22 Osprey that crashed almost a week earlier has been found with 5 crew members' bodies inside, the Air Force confirmed.

articles.description: Dr. Sultan al-Jaber, president of the COP28 climate conference and CEO of a major oil company, says he's "quite surprised" by what he calls "attempts to undermine" his work.

articles.description: After nearly being destroyed in a fire over four years ago, Notre Dame's new spire is being installed after the original collapsed in the 2019 blaze. Elaine Cobbe reports.

articles.description: As the war between Israel and Hamas resumes, U.S. officials are urging Israel to try to minimize civilian casualties. Thousands of Palestinians have already been killed in the conflict. Nicole Sganga reports.

articles.description: The release of Palestinian prisoners during the weeklong cease-fire has brought renewed criticism over Israel's detention policies. According to the U.N., between 500 and 1,000 Palestinian children in the West Bank are held in Israeli military detention despite not being charged with any crimes. Imtiaz Tyab reports.

articles.description: Israel's military continues to pummel Gaza following the end of a temporary cease-fire to allow for the release of hostages. Some 130 hostages, including eight Americans, remain in the Gaza Strip. Chris Livesay reports.

articles.description: U.S. officials said drones and missiles were fired at 3 commercial vessels in the Red Sea on Sunday.

articles.description: Israel dismissed warnings leading up to the terrorist attack, Rep. Mike Turner, the chair of the House Intelligence Committee, said.
articles.title: U.S. assisting Israel to find intelligence "gaps," Turner says

articles.description: With the collapse of the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas earlier this week, the Hamas-held hostages and the people of Gaza are once again caught in the crucible of war. Chris Livesay has the latest.
articles.title: Israel intensifies airstrikes on Gaza

articles.description: With thousands of civilians killed in Gaza in the war, National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby tells "Face the Nation" that the U.S. has been helping Israel be as "to be as careful and as precise and as deliberate in their targeting" of Hamas as possible.
articles.title: U.S. helping Israel be as "precise" in targeting Hamas, NSC spokesperson John Kirby says

articles.description: House Intelligence Committee chair Rep. Mike Turner, Republican of Ohio, tells "Face the Nation" that there was a "complete breakdown" of Israeli intelligence ahead of the Oct. 7 attack, and the U.S. is now assisting Israel to find the "gaps" in intelligence and help find Hamas leadership.
articles.title: U.S. assisting Israel to find intelligence "gaps" ahead of Oct. 7 attack. Rep. Mike Turner says

articles.description: With the cease-fire in shambles, Israel Defense Forces resumed their advance in Gaza while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insists the ground operation gives Israel leverage to free the remaining 130 hostages who remain in the hands of Hamas. This weekend in Qatar, Israeli intelligence sent a team to continue negotiations with Hamas, but hours later, that team turned around saying "Hamas did not uphold its part of the agreement, which included the release of all of the women and children." Chris Livesay reports.
articles.title: Israel Defense Forces resume Gaza advance while Hamas still holds 130 hostages

articles.description: Phasing out fossil fuels has been a heated debate at the U.N. Climate Change Conference, known as COP28, in Dubai, and many climate activists fear the process has been compromised by being held in the oil rich United Arab Emirates. The Biden administration has touted record levels of federal funding for clean energy projects, but the U.S. is also producing record amounts of crude oil. Ben Tracy reports.
articles.title: Fossil fuel debate takes center stage at COP28

articles.description: Renowned for dependable hospitality and ritualized etiquette, Japan now has one restaurant where the service is dependably, defiantly atrocious. At the Lazy House in Nagoya, the dining experience is turned on its head, with a cranky and petulant staff dishing out insults while tossing dinner plates. Correspondent Lucy Craft checks out why the rude restaurant, launched last summer, has become an instant comic hit on social media.
articles.title: In Japan one restaurant prides itself on its rudeness

articles.description: A guidance system problem during final approach prompted two space station cosmonauts to take over by remote control.

articles.description: A 7.6-magnitude earthquake struck off the southern coast of the Philippines Saturday night, prompting a tsunami warning. There were no immediate reports of significant damage or injuries.

articles.description: The man killed in the attack was a German tourist, the French interior minister told reporters.

articles.description: A coalition of 50 major oil and gas companies are expected to agree to significantly cut their methane emissions by the end of the decade at the COP28 climate summit, marking a potential breakthrough in the fight against climate change. Ben Tracy has more on why methane is such a problem and the new tools designed to hold the industry accountable.

articles.description: Nicaraguan police say they want to arrest the director of the Miss Nicaragua pageant, accusing her of intentionally rigging contests so that anti-government beauty queens would win the pageants as part of a plot to overthrow the government.

articles.description: After a week-long cease-fire that saw dozens of Hamas hostages released in exchange for hundreds of Palestinian prisoners being held in Israel, the violence has resumed in Gaza. Israel said it had struck more than 400 targets in the territory, while the Hamas-run Gaza Health Ministry said 240 civilians have died since the end of the cease-fire. Lilia Luciano is in Tel Aviv with more.

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.description: NEW YORK — The French Alps will likely host the 2030 Winter Olympics, with Salt Lake City following in 2034, the International Olympic Committee announced Wednesday. Two regions in southeast France — Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes and Provence-Alpes-Côte d’Azur — made a joint bid to host the 2030 Games and were selected for exclusive negotiations with the IOC. The French beat out bids from Sweden and Switzerland to host the 2030 Winter Olympics. The IOC plans to officially announce a winner in July. That will give the successful bid just over five years to plan for the Games, the tightest turnaround in ...
articles.title: French Alps on fast track to host 2030 Winter Olympics, Salt Lake City set for 2034

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
The Justice Department announced charges against an Indian man who's accused of directing an assassination plot. 
Nikhil "Nick" Gupta was charged on Wednesday after an Indian government employee who works on security and intelligence encouraged him to take out a Sikh activist who supports a sovereign state in northern India, the Department of Justice said.
The defendant conspired from India to assassinate, right here in New York City, a U.S. citizen of Indian origin who has publicly advocated for the establishment of a sovereign state for Sikhs," said Manhattan prosecutor Damian Williams in a statement.
It's the second such incident announced in the past week. According to President Joe Biden's administration, investigators foiled another plot to kill a Sikh separatist in the United States.
Among the most startling details in the Justice Department's statement is an alleged revelation from Gupta to an undercover DEA agent that another Sikh leader, Hardeep Singh Nijjar, "was also the target." 
In fact, he revealed, "We have so many targets."
ALSO READ: You might think the NFL is racist. An insider says he’s about to prove it in court.
Sikh groups, including some active in the United States and Canada, have vocally advocated for their own state to be parsed out of India. 
The Diplomat detailed leaked Pakistani documents it says point to an assassination program being orchestrated by India, though the site claimed the leak is attempting to capitalize on India's negative publicity. 
The Intercept's report last week also cited the same intelligence assessment, saying that the Indian government's "Research and Analysis Wing" has been plotting a global assassination plot in several countries in a coordinated effort to target Sikh and Kashmiri activists abroad. 
Read the full court filing by the DOJ here.
articles.title: Indian man charged with assassination plot aimed at Sikh activist in NYC

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Ever since Hamas's deadly October 7 attack on southern Israel, the father of 17-year-old hostage Mia Leimberg had been praying for her safe release from captivity in Gaza -- and the return of the family pet.
To Moshe Leimberg's great joy, his daughter was finally freed on Tuesday as part of a group of hostages 12 -- 10 Israelis and two Thais -- that also included her mother and aunt.
And the release of the hostages under an agreement to pause fighting between Israel and Hamas also solved the mystery of what happened to Mia's pet dog Bella.
At the time of the Palestinian militant group's attack, the dog had been with Mia on the southern Israeli kibbutz of Nir Yitzhak, where she and her mother Gabriela had been visiting her aunt.
Leimberg searched for the fluffy white dog in the aftermath of the assault -- in which around 240 hostages were taken, Israeli officials say -- hoping it would be a comfort for his daughter when she finally returned, Israeli daily Israel Hayom reported.
The fate of the animal became clear on Tuesday when pictures were beamed around the world of Mia -- flanked by masked and armed fighters from Hamas and militant group the Islamic Jihad -- being handed over to Red Cross officials.
She was carrying Bella in her arms, which it now appears was with her all along.
Israeli officials say the Hamas attack on October 7 killed around 1,200 people, most of them civilians.
In response, Israel has vowed to eliminate Hamas and has unleashed an air and ground campaign that the Hamas government says has killed more than 15,000 people, also mostly civilians.
© 2023 AFP
articles.title: Release of Israeli teenage hostage ends mystery over lost dog

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
From Hamas's brutal attacks in Israel, and the fierce retribution it provoked, to the kiss that caused a revolt in Spanish football, here are 10 events that marked a tumultuous 2023:
Israel-Gaza war
On October 7, hundreds of Hamas gunmen pour across the border from Gaza, killing around 1,200 people, mostly civilians, and taking about 240 people hostage in the worst attack in Israel's history, traumatizing the country and stunning the world.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vows to "destroy" Hamas and Israel launches air bombardments followed by a ground offensive that reduces entire neighborhoods in the densely packed Palestinian territory to rubble.
As Gaza's destruction and death toll mount, international pressure grows on Israel to pause it's offensive.
Seven weeks into the war, the tw…
articles.title: From the Israel-Gaza war to the Moon race: events that defined 2023

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Pope Francis presided over his weekly audience Wednesday despite the flu that caused him to scrap a trip to Dubai, but asked an aide to deliver his reading for him.
The Argentine pontiff, 86, looked tired and sounded breathless as he told the audience at the Vatican that "I'm still not well with this flu".
Francis, who had part of a lung removed when he was younger, was forced Tuesday to cancel his scheduled trip to key UN climate talks, following advice from his doctors.
The pope had been due to travel to Dubai from Friday to Sunday, but is suffering from an inflammation of the respiratory tract, Vatican spokesman Matteo Bruni said.
Francis spoke at the end of Wednesday's audience to call for an end to the wars in Gaza and Ukraine, wheezing as he did so.
But he looked cheered by a circus performance put on for him, complete with acrobats on roller skates.
And before the general audience he told visiting members of the Celtic football club that he was feeling "better than yesterday".
The pope, who turns 87 next month, has suffered a series of health issues in recent years, from knee and hip pain to an inflamed colon and most recently, hernia surgery in June.
He was also hospitalized for three nights in March with bronchitis, which was cured with antibiotics.
On Saturday, he cancelled events due to what the Vatican called "light flu symptoms".
It said that a CT scan had ruled out "risks of pulmonary complications" and Francis was receiving antibiotics intravenously.
© 2023 AFP
articles.title: Breathless pope delegates reading as flu persists

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
On the outskirts of the eastern German town of Wittenberg, a corrugated iron gate painted with green leaves welcomes visitors to the "Koenigreich Deutschland" (Kingdom of Germany).
Those who step through the gate to the cluster of buildings on the other side are entering place that styles itself a country, complete with its own flag, laws, currency and ID cards.
The so-called Kingdom of Germany was founded by former chef and karate teacher Peter Fitzek, who anointed himself as "king" in 2012 in an elaborate ceremony complete with a crown and scepter.
Fitzek and his followers are part of a movement known as the Reichsbuerger (Citizens of the Reich), a loose grouping of in some cases violent extremists and conspiracy theorists who reject the legitimacy of the modern German republic.
Long dis…
articles.title: 'Citizens of the Reich': Raids and suspicion as German group grows

articles.author: Jessica Corbett, Common Dreams
articles.description:
With the world hurtling toward catastrophic temperature rise, "Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is overseeing a sweeping global investment program" intended to "ensure that emerging economies across Africa and Asia become vastly more dependent on oil" even as the international community tries to phase out planet-heating fossil fuels.
That's according to a sixth-month undercover investigation by the U.K.'s Center for Climate Reporting (CCR) and Channel 4 News, based on regulatory filings, documents from Saudi officials, and secret recordings.
The findings were published Monday in the leadup to the United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP28) set to kick off Thursday in the United Arab Emirates.
As CCR detailed:
The Oil Demand Sustainability Program (OSP) is a vast government progr…
articles.title: 'Cartoonishly villainous' Saudi plot to hook poor nations on oil exposed

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
DUBAI (Reuters) — The leaders of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and Israel's Mossad met Qatar's prime minister in Doha on Tuesday to build on the two-day extension of a truce between Israel and the Palestinian group Hamas, a source briefed on the visit said. 
The meeting was "to build on the progress of the extended humanitarian pause agreement and to initiate further discussions about the next phase of a potential deal," the source told Reuters. 
The outcome of the talks, which were also attended by Egyptian officials, was unclear, the source added.
articles.title: Israeli, U.S. spy chiefs meet Qatari PM to discuss 'building on' Gaza truce: source

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Cheers and jubilation erupted as rescuers in India on Tuesday brought out 41 construction workers who were trapped in a collapsed tunnel in the Himalayas for 17 days, hours after drilling through the debris of rock, concrete and earth to reach them.
"I am completely relieved and happy as 41 trapped laborers in the Silkyara Tunnel Collapse have been successfully rescued," Minister of Road Transport Nitin Gadkari said in a statement. "This was a well-coordinated effort by multiple agencies, marking one of the most significant rescue operations in recent years."
 © Uttarkashi District Information via Reuters
The rescued men were draped in orange marigold flower garlands in celebration as they were greeted by state officials as a line of ambulances waited to receive them.
The men, low-wage wor…
articles.title: Indian workers trapped in collapsed tunnel rescued after 17 days

articles.author: Jake Johnson, Common Dreams
articles.description:
With his approval ratings in the tank, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has reportedly been lobbying members of his Likud party in a bid to keep their support, claiming he is "the only one who will prevent a Palestinian state" in Gaza and the West Bank.

Netanyahu's remarks, first reported by the Israeli public broadcaster Kan, fly in the face of the Biden administration's continued push for a two-state solution as the "only way to guarantee the long-term security of both the Israeli and the Palestinian people."
"To make sure Israelis and Palestinians alike live in equal measure of freedom and dignity, we will not give up on working towards that goal," U.S. President Joe Biden, who has offered unconditional political and military support to Israel during its latest assault on Gaza…
articles.title: Netanyahu says he is 'only one who will prevent a Palestinian state'

articles.author: Brad Reed
articles.description:
For years, former President Donald Trump has avoided agreeing with intelligence assessments that Russian President Vladimir Putin interfered on his behalf during the 2016 presidential election.
Most infamously, Trump rejected the American intelligence community's assessment about Russia's actions at a press conference in Helsinki, Finland where he stood next to Putin and said, "President Putin says it's not Russia, I don't see any reason why it would be."
But it seems that Trump will actually blame Putin for 2016 election interference if doing so will help keep him out of prison.
Politico's Kyle Cheney flags a legal filing by Trump's attorneys this week in which they dispute special counsel Jack Smith's claims that Trump has damaged Americans' faith in the electoral system by essentially arguing that Putin did it first.
"The Special Counsel's Office falsely alleges that President Trump 'eroded public faith in the administration of the election,'" the filing states. "The 2016 [Intelligence Community Assessment] uses strikingly similar language to attribute the origins of that erosion to foreign influence -- that is, foreign efforts to 'undermine public faith in the U.S. democratic process.'"
The filing went on to argue that "President Trump is entitled to the detailed information supporting the conclusions in the 2016 Election ICA... in order to demonstrate to a jury that he did not create or cause the environment that the prosecution seeks to blame him for."
What Trump's lawyers leave out is the fact that Trump openly encouraged Russia to hack political rival Hillary Clinton's email server and release her private communications.
When Russia eventually leaked hacked emails from Clinton's campaign to WikiLeaks, Trump eagerly promoted them while on the campaign trail as evidence of Clinton's purported corruption.
articles.title: Trump finally pins the blame on Putin in new bid to stay out of jail

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Far-right, anti-Islam Dutch politician Geert Wilders sought to kick-start the arduous process of forming a coalition on Tuesday, still reeling from the collapse of initial efforts before talks had even begun.
Wilders, whose stunning general election win on Wednesday sent shock waves through the Netherlands and the whole of Europe, put forward a fresh candidate for a "scout" to oversee the coalition horse-trading.
His first appointment, Gom Van Strien, was forced to step down on Monday following allegations of fraud at a previous company. "Not my dream start," admitted Wilders.
After a brief meeting of top party leaders, Wilders' new candidate, former Labour Party education minister Ronald Plasterk, won "broad support", according to Lower House chairwoman Vera Bergkamp.
"It is important tha…
articles.title: Far-right Wilders in fresh bid to form Dutch govt after false start

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis expressed his "displeasure" Monday over UK counterpart Rishi Sunak's last minute cancellation of a bilateral meeting set to discuss their long-running dispute over the Parthenon Marbles.
The two leaders were due to hold talks midday Tuesday in London, where Mitsotakis has been visiting since Sunday, before news of their axing emerged late Monday amid an apparent spat over the so-called Elgin Marbles.
"I would like to express my displeasure at the British Prime Minister's cancellation of our meeting just a few hours before it was due to take place," the Greek leader said in a brief statement.
He reportedly declined a UK offer to meet Deputy Prime Minister Oliver Dowden instead.
A Downing Street spokesperson said "the UK-Greece relationship is hugely …
articles.title: Greek PM unhappy after UK's Sunak cancels talks amid Parthenon marbles spat

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo said on Monday she was quitting Elon Musk's social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, which she described as a "global sewer" and a tool to disrupt democracy.
"I've made the decision to leave X," Hidalgo said in an op-ed in French newspaper Le Monde. "X has in recent years become a weapon of mass destruction of our democracies", she wrote.
The 64-year-old Socialist, who unsuccessfully stood for the presidency in 2022, joined Twitter as it was then known in 2009 and has been a frequent user of the platform.
She accused X of promoting "misinformation", "anti-Semitism and racism."
"The list of abuses is endless", she added. "This media has become a vast global sewer."
Since Musk took over Twitter in 2022, a number of high-profile figures said they were leaving the popular social platform, but there has been no mass exodus.
Several politicians including EU industry chief Thierry Breton have announced that they are opening accounts on competing networks in addition to maintaining their presence on X.
The City of Paris account will remain on X, the mayor's office told AFP.
By contrast, some organisations have taken the plunge, including the US public radio network NPR, or the German anti-discrimination agency.
Hidalgo has regularly faced personal attacks on social media including Twitter, as well as sometimes criticism over the lack of cleanliness and security in Paris.
(AFP)
articles.title: Paris mayor quits X, calling social media platform a 'vast global sewer'

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
New documents surfaced in September indicating that Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel may have played a double role during World War II, serving not only as an informant for the Nazis but also as a member of the French Resistance. But a historian who has analysed the new evidence says he has “serious doubts” about her alleged membership in La Résistance, suggesting the French fashion icon may have used the documents to restore her reputation after the war.
The previously unseen documents were revealed to the public in mid-September at the opening of a London exhibition tracing the life and legacy of the French couturier. Alongside more than 50 of Chanel’s iconic tweed suits and a whole room dedicated to Chanel No. 5 perfume, a part of the “Gabrielle Chanel: Fashion Manifesto” retrospective also deal…
articles.title: Historian debunks claims that Coco Chanel served in the French Resistance

articles.author: AFP
articles.description:
British airline Virgin Atlantic on Tuesday operates the first transatlantic flight powered entirely by Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), but environmental groups criticized the event as "greenwashing".
The flight will leave London's Heathrow airport at 1130 GMT bound for New York's JFK.
It is the first time that SAF will be used "in both engines, by a commercial airline, for long-haul flight", the airline said in a statement.
However, the Boeing 787 plane equipped with Rolls-Royce engines will not carry any paying passengers or cargo.
SAFs are produced from renewable biomass and waste resources and can be used in jet fuel to a maximum of 50 percent, having been blended with kerosene, in modern aircraft.
They are seen as the main tool for decarbonizing the aviation sector over the coming dec…
articles.title: Virgin set for first long-haul flight with low-carbon fuel

articles.description: MOSCOW (Reuters) -A Russian court has extended the pre-trial detention of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich for two months until Jan. 30, 2024, the court's press service said on Tuesday. Gershkovich was arrested on March 29 in the Urals city of Yekaterinburg on charges of espionage that carry up to 20 years in prison. The reporter denies the charges. "The court ruled to extend the term of detention of Gershkovich, accused of a crime under Article 276 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation, for up to 10 months, that is, until January 30, 2024," Moscow's Lefortovo district co...
articles.title: Russian court extends pre-trial detention for WSJ reporter Gershkovich

articles.description: By Soo-hyang Choi SEOUL (Reuters) - North Korea on Tuesday made a rare mention of dissenting votes in recent elections, although analysts dismissed it as an attempt to portray an image of a normal society rather than signalling any meaningful increase of rights in the authoritarian state. The reclusive North has one of the most highly controlled societies in the world, with leader Kim Jong Un accused of using a system of patronage and repression to retain absolute power. Reporting on the results of Sunday's election for deputies to regional people's assemblies, the North's state media said 0.0...

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: By Josh Smith and Hyonhee Shin SEOUL (Reuters) -After decades of satellite surveillance by foreign governments and analysts, North Korea has sent its first spy satellite on a global orbit with a message to the world: we can watch you too. On Tuesday North Korean state media said leader Kim Jong Un had reviewed spy satellite photos of the White House, Pentagon and U.S. aircraft carriers at the naval base of Norfolk. North Korea last week successfully launched its first reconnaissance satellite, which it has said was designed to monitor U.S. and South Korean military movements. Since then state ...
articles.title: North Korea says its new spy satellite photographed White House, Pentagon
